ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I gained some improvements to my writing but the biggest insight came from the course content and readings of the course about work.
I learned how to formulate arguments better and I learned a lot about the nature of work.
Writing skills improved to a certain degree.
I learned about some of the different labor industries and how they are related. I also learned about how to better write an essay.
I deepened my understanding of writing and labor relations in this class.

This course significantly helped to improve my writing skills and helped with the transition from high school level writing to college level writing. The specific articles chosen and the unit analyzing art both improved my ability to evaluate a topic or issue from several point of views, displaying the multitude of argument points thats could be taken regarding various art forms.
I learned the fundamentals of academic writing in a variety of essay forms. How a modern essay is structured and the rhetorical methods that help make an argument.
I gained a lot of critical thinking and analysis skills and also learned a lot of important writing skills which will be important for my future days at Yale.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The small classroom setting was beneficial and it was a good first year writing course.
The course was taught very well/

Strenghts - diversity of graded tasks (ranging from critical analysis to reflective writing) as well as the diversity of assigned readings (ranging from Karl Marx's Communist Manifesto to Uberland).
Weaknesses - Expectations were somewhat basic in nature and as a result we were never really pushed to improve or change the way we write substantially

This class was facilitated often with engaging and interesting work, allowing me to focus on the content and my involvement in it. My only real improvements would be that my class was not all that engaged.

A strength of this course was that we got direct feedback on our essays with comments on where we could improve and what we could specifically do to improve. A weakness was that during class discussions, there were oftentimes where a question would be asked, and the class was silent with no one answering until a new question was asked.
The course did an excellent job of grouping relevant readings together that demonstrated the type of essay we were supposed to be writing.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I would recommend this course because it was a good intro to writing in general and with longer papers that may be expected in later courses.
Yes

Yes! It's a great WR credit for most first-years, especially if you get the section you want during preference selection. Definitely take this class with Daniel Swain if possible (and if he continues teaching 114 in the following years). Great instructor, very chill and cooperative when it came to deadlines - also extremely knowledgeable and helpful as a mentor
Yes. Daniel Swain was an excellent teacher and the material of the course was very interesting.
I would recommend this course, Professor Swain was absolutely excellent in his teaching and student participation.

Yes, I would recommend this course as an intro class at Yale, because it will help your writing a lot and the skills learned in this class can be applied to all current and future classes you can take.

Yes, the structure made the class easy to learn and understandable. The readings were interesting and relevant to what we were supposed to be writing. The overall discussion that the instructor facilitated was lively and exciting.
Yes, I would. I think that this course gave me a new perspective on the nature of work and labor which I will carry with me and I would recommend anyone who is interested in this.
